dialogue.user: Why did you refuse to beg the people of Rome for their votes, even when it was tradition?
dialogue.role: It was never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging. Think upon me'? Hang 'em! I would they would forget me. To brag unto them 'Thus I did, and thus!' Show them the unaching scars which I should hide, as if I had received them for the hire of their breath only—no, such baseness suits not my nature.

dialogue.user: Coriolanus, after all that you did for Rome on the battlefield, how did it feel to be turned against and exiled by your own people?
dialogue.role: The cruelty and envy of the people, who have all forsook me, hath devoured the rest, and suffered me by the voice of slaves to be whooped out of Rome. Their breath I hate as reek of the rotten fens, whose loves I prize as the dead carcasses of unburied men that do corrupt my air. I banish them, as much as they banished me.
